The ceasefire in Syria has entered its third day at this point. There has been significant Russian military buildup regarding ground troops as well as naval forces and air forces. Meanwhile the secretary-general of NATO states that "there are no plans about NATO providing ground troops for the military operations in Syria." France was the country that specifically asked for the task force overseeing the cessation of hostilities meet immediately. The French Foreign Affairs Minister said himself that France "fervently wants an end to hostilities." He also asked that the UN Security Council take those guilty of violations in Syria to the International Criminal Court. If anything I think that France is looking to de-escalate involvement.

France has been integral in implementing the cease-fire between Assad and "moderate rebel" groups in Syria, which has largely held. France used air power to target ISIS following the latest terrorist attacks against it, and barring further escalation, there is no reason to think it will go it alone in the next months. C- compare to response to previous terror attacks, response in Libya, H- statements by French officials, K- preferences of NATO leaders not to be involved in another ground war, N: UN Security Council politics, particularly Russian support of Syrian state sovereignty, preclude the international coalition likely to accompany French ground troops.

That unguarded Mediterranean coastline provides a far simpler approach.

+8 based on links & analyses of @Clairvoyance & @aaseawaf15.  We have a two-step forecast: 1) Will the troops be deployed? and, if so 2) Will deployment be credibly reported? Because I believe the coalition is building to a major offensive campaign (which I also believe focuses the French upon Syria), and I believe the "best practice" is always to allow a period of reconnaissance, intelligence gathering, and acclimation, I have been leaning towards "Yes" as to the first part of the two-step process. [Edit: And for those who suggest that French SF may have already been there, I would suggest an increased tempo and scope as to their activities.] I could place some probability on the first step, but taking Le Drian's "hint" as a confirmation, and for computational simplicity, I'm just going to assume it to be "yes." The aforementioned is just a long way of saying we are faced with forecasting the probability that these (assumed to be) deployed troops will be reported upon. This is challenging because, except for very rare glimpses, it is a controlled information environment.
- French "long-standing policy of never discussing the deployment of its elite troops." Certainly an excellent operational security policy and one that would likely be respected by the vast majority of Western news sources and outlets.
+ The assumption that LeDrian is sophisticated enough to recognize that even a "hint" is a violation of that policy, which therefore requires the additional assumption that LeDrian had some sufficient reason to violate that policy. Would the desire to generate a signal of coalition solidarity be sufficient reason? Is there some perceived need to demonstrate some active effort to a domestic audience? Perhaps this reason, whatever it may be, will continue.
+ There are some reputable non-Western sources and outlets who may have an independent interest in the report; which can only now be enhanced by, perhaps, the professional ambition of some intrepid journalist to pop the "hint" bubble that Le Drian has created.
- The nature of the activities are covert, often in "the dark" both figuratively and literally. Not a lot of free-floating witnesses who don't have their back turned to the action as they are running away. Also, maybe the "hint" indicates the French SF are embedded within some U.S. SF group(s), making distinctive identification difficult.
+/- The one perhaps relevant incident we have is that of a Canadian special force contingent. No news was generated by this contingent until they were placed under a crazy banzai-like attack (my description) by ISIL. If ISIL really is feeling the pressure, it is possible the frequency of such "crazy" attacks might increase, thus perhaps drawing attention to a French SF contingent.

Think about the case of the gradual escalation of US military involvement in Vietnam, when a long period of sending Special Forces and military advisers to support the Diem regime under President Kennedy was followed by the first deployment of combat troops (Marines) in 1965 under LBJ. Read any history of the Vietnam War and it will state that the first US combat troops were sent under LBJ, not Kennedy.
